text: hi everyone lemon and lime here the
internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
the new proto martyr album
ultimate success today this is the
latest lp from post and art punk
revivalists protomartyr
a detroit band that is now on their
fifth full-length lp
out now via domino records it's been
about three years since the release of
the band's last full-length lp relatives
in descent
my favorite record of their so far
there's certainly something about the
band's downtrodden brand of
bad seeds esque sad punk that feels so
urgent
so intense and as nasty as the world
that gave birth to it
proto martyrs artistic evolution has
been defined so far
more by fine tuning than great leaps and
radical changes with their post punk
style becoming less and less boilerplate
over time
so i didn't go into ultimate success
today expecting
a huge difference in sound but i do
sense some subtle changes in approach
that haven't
exactly resulted in the band's best
material yet but for the most part
ultimate success today sounds exactly
like the proto martyr
that fans have known and loved for
however many years you've been
aware of them aesthetically this record
checks all of the usual boxes and on top
of it adds some
hulking climaxes of noisy
instrumentation
some sacks and cello and flute here and
there as well
but the way the band is formulating the
songs on this record it feels a lot more
linear this time around
as if the idea behind multiple tracks
here is to harp on a single
phrase or groove and intensify it until
it becomes a hulking mass
which hey that's literally what some of
my favorite bands of all time do
the issue for me though is that i don't
necessarily think proto martyr
is the best at it because there are
multiple moments on this thing that just
leave me
scratching my head like with the day
without end intro the more this tracks
eerie ringing guitar leads and driving
sixteenth note hi-hats lose control
the less gratifying it becomes
miraculously and while i'm aware this
is an intro track a starter a taster the
abrupt ending
still makes the song feel like the build
bill bill
bill build progression it undergoes is
just for nothing
at the end following this we have the
track processed by the boys which does
feature some of the most cacophonous and
exciting passages on the entire record
but
what is the rest of this instrumental
the
shrill and shimmering reverb heavy
guitar chords that sync up with the
pronounced drumming on the track
sound like something out of a grizzly
bear song but
dragged out to the point where it gets
really tiresome so that's the start of
the record and the end of the lp can get
pretty underwhelming too
there is bridge and crown which is a
slow burner in 3-4
who's tedious progression and pacing
only seems to reveal more drab guitar
leads and super shrill chords
then as the song moves forward and the
band begins to fill in the gaps
in the instrumental the whole thing just
sounds more and more mushy
then with worm and heaven we have a very
forlorn closer who's instrumental i
think could have used a little something
extra especially in the first half
the greatest selling point of the song
ends up being front man joe casey
who pulls off a super theatrical
performance packed with some of the most
poetically tragic lyrics on the entire
record for me many of the performances
sit in a weird middle ground where
they're not hectic enough to be
a thrilling mess but not tight enough to
be conventionally appealing either
and while this may not ruin a given song
it does leave me wanting more
take for example the track modern
business hymns
the driving dance beat combined with
these swaggered but sloppily strum
guitar chords and
awkward leads sounds like the strokes if
they were decked out in goth attire and
high out of their minds
i do got to give credit where it's due
though there are some points where the
band really does hit the nail on the
head
i am you now is a pretty fiery track
with its
driving floor toms mega abrasive guitar
chords that hit like a shock to the
system it's like i'm being just woken up
with a defibrillator
joe casey also on this track sounding
like he's on the verge of a
manic episode with his dramatic shouted
poetry
then as the track cools down the band
actually moves through a series of
very incremental but engaging and
enjoyable
progressions that bring things to a
really gratifying climax the pacing is
there the subtlety is there it's great
then the aphorist sees the band visiting
somewhat familiar territory with a grim
dirty ballad very despondent moment in
the tracklist that hits with an
emotional punch and a sonic one two
as the band immediately transitions in
the second half
into the screaming ghoulish instrumental
bridge and solo passage
we also have the absolutely sinister
june 21st which
features some extra vocals i believe
from nandy rose halfway
which certainly adds to the song's
frightening tone especially on
its icy hook summer in the city bring me
no
also the pulsating tangy guitar leads
create
quite the groove with the drums on this
track and i love the way all this
very quiet subtle instrumentation is
droning away in the background on these
verses
getting a bit more intense as it goes
along it sounds like it's there
but it's also not it's kind of maddening
then the song tranquilizer another
highlight for me
is anything but tranquil it's actually
the nastiest
sounding song on the entire record
arguably the nocturnal sax leads and
disgustingly distorted bass lines
combined with joe casey's voice that has
this
very springy very immediate delay on it
there's something about the the start of
this song it sort of sounds like a
cramps record
then almost without warning the band
breaks into some of the noisiest walls
of sound on the entire lp
cool they saved some of the most
abrasive sounds for the second half
though i will say the verse beyond this
point does
sound like the group is kind of killing
time to
put you into a lull so they can hit you
with that wall of noise once again but
i don't know it's worth another go
around i suppose and
that's kind of it in terms of highlights
for me sadly granted the other
tracks on the lp aren't terrible but i
did expect more from this thing in terms
of performances and songwriting which
arguably were better on relatives and
agent intellect
even some portions of under color of
official right
where the band's amateurishness was at
least an endearing factor
meanwhile ultimate success today feels
unkempt without an
explanation even though partially i can
appreciate the band
trying to change things up a little
instrumentally this time around
along with the increased focus on
sociopolitical topics
in the lyrics these respectable changes
didn't result in one of my favorite
records in the band's catalog
sadly feeling a decent six on this one
tran position have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
for the best what should i review next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head is another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano music proto martyr
forever
